campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.URLS¶

dict – Contains forest names and the url to the camping-cabins page for each forest.

campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.find_elevation_div(tag)[source]¶

Helper to find tags about elevation.

Parameters:tag (bs4.element.tag) – Tag from BeautifulSoup parsed HTML site.
Returns:
True when the text ‘elevation’ was found in the tag’s contents,
False if not.
Return type:bool

campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.find_tag_containing_text(tag, text)[source]¶

BeautifulSoup find_all function to find tags that contain a text pattern

Since find_all does not take any args, it must be wrapped with another function so that the text pattern can be passed.

Parameters:
  • tag (bs4.element.tag) – Tag from BeautifulSoup parsed HTML site.
  • text (str) – text to search a tag’s elements for. Case insensitive.
Returns:

True when the text was found in the tag’s contents, False

if not.
Return type:

bool

See also

  • find_elevation_div()
  • find_latitude_div()
  • find_longitude_tag()

find_elevation_div: func1 find_latitude_div: func2

campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.find_value(soup, tag_function)[source]¶

Gets the value in the element after the first found tag.

This is used to scrape the table in the campground’s side bar that contains elevation, latitude, and longitude data. These data are in divs, not an HTML table. For example, the data for elevation is in the div after the div that contains the text “elevation”. This function finds the first tag containing certain text, then returns the contents of the first sibling after that element.

Parameters:
  • soup (bs4.BeautifulSoup) – Parsed HTML text of campground website.
  • tag_function (func) – function to find tags whose contents contain the desired text.
Returns:

Contents of the element after the tag that contains the

searched-for text.
Return type:

str

Examples

>>> find_value(soup, find_elevation_tag)
'5,000 ft'

See also

  • get_campground_data()
campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.get_campground_data(url)[source]¶

Scrapes all the desired data for a campground.

Collects all of the data in the “At a Glance” section of the campground webpage, and elevation, longitude, and latitude on the side of the webpage and stores it in a dictionary. The dictionary is then converted to a pandas.DataFrame, which will eventually be a row in the final table.

Parameters:url (str) – URL to the campground webpage.
Returns:
single-row table with columns of all the
data that was scraped.
Return type:pandas.DataFrame

See also

  • scrape_campsite_data()
campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.get_campground_urls(forest_url)[source]¶

Retrieves all the urls for campgrounds in a national forest.

Parameters:forest_url (str) – URL to the camping-cabins page of the NFS site
Returns:
with the inner list’s first element being
the campground name, and the second element being the URL for the campground.
Return type:list(list(str, ))

See also

  • scrape_all_forests()

campstatus.scrape_campsite_data.scrape_campsite_data(urls)[source]¶

Creates a table of campground data given a list of campground URLs.

Parameters:urls (list(str, )) – list of URLs pointing to campground webpages
Returns:
Table of all the aggregated data from all
the campgrounds pointed to by urls. Each row is one campground.
Return type:pandas.DataFrame
